AMD REVIEWS


Edward Banks

in.


If you can no longer muster
enough energy to mail a we'll
worn heel to the shoemaker--Go
out to yournearest shoe store
and buy a pair of sneakers. Come
home and spray them a bright
color-then start a new fad--wear
a shocking pink pair Of sneakers
at your next party. Then smile
when everyone abandons skinny
heels and wears sneakers in
stead.

spike heeled shoes.


Skinny heels have helped the
American economy by providing
more work for the shoe repair
men and more work for the gar
deners. They have increased
the wear on tiled floors and they
have increased the sales of shoe
tote bags. Now women must not
only wear a pair of shoes to COM
plement their outfits. but they
must have an extra pair to walk

An average college student in
the US. will spend 1000 hours
in classes, seminars and lab
oratories during his four years
on campus and 1000 hours in
extracurrfcular activitof one
sort or another.

The average US. farm is ESQ
acres.


The average American family
sends IS Christmas cards and
manages to get "a per cent Of
them to arrive before Dec. Is.

Last walk around Cne cor IleT
in a. pair Of the latest slimheeled
pur4p brought cries Of distress
from me. stepped nimbly
across the pavement and imme-
diately my shoe was wedged in a
long crack in the concrete. The
tiny4heel became imprisoned and
wrenched my ankle as tried to
continue forward.


This heel episode has been re-
peated several times in many
places. Yes, have been stopped
cold in many streets and side
walks, here and abroad. could
easily compose testimonials
about sidewalks have been
trapped in.


Shoe heels began to complicate
mans flat and barefoot existence
when the peasants donned broad
heeled ones.


The idle and wealthy ones we're
able to accept the stylish heel for
display at the court. Riding
heeled noblemen could be easily
distinguished from a mere foot
soldier who needed a mere thong
type shoe.


Those tall heels of Enzabe-
thean days we're not worn by all,
but | am sure those who wore
them didn't try mile hike be-
fore dinner.


My heel IS nearly two inches
wide and most Of my dress shoes
have heels which are less than
five-eighths Of an inch wide. AS
l rock and reel on these heels
which are from two to three
inches high-I fret about the
fashion editors who maintain slim
and high heels are beautiful.


In the United States there is
only one way to exercise your
ideas against something the
women who are tired of these
heels must organize. We must
form society or ladies who are
ready to petition the shoe manu-
facturers. the shoe wholesalers,
the shoe retailers, the shoe re-
paitfnen and our state legisla-
tors--and even our congressman.


This battle of the heels must 60
forward--women are being duped
into believing that a precarious
walk around town in understood
and unsafe heels is adding to our
feminine appeal and style.


Have you ever watched fair
damsel who is we'll dressed but
slightly off balance as she treads
along the streets of our fair city,


There she is Miss or Mrs.
USA--immaculately attired with
matching or contrasting apparel
but there she steps as gingerly
as a polecat on an oily street.
She wants to look down and test
her footing, she wants to avoid
the seams in the sidewalk. and
remain poised and graceful.


Nothing can spoil the effect
as much as small hole in the
asphalt or a crack in the cement.
Imagine my chagrin when we
we're strolling down main street
in Madrid. Edward, my beloved
spouse was taking his giant steps
and chatting with me. Suddenly
was trapped. Myheel was stuck
fast in hole between the cobble-
stones. A few passersby smiled
as tried valiantly to extricate
my shoe. Finally my husband
realized | was not in step and
turned and asked me to hurry
along.


At other times | have been
caught in the small holes of rub
Der door mats. | have tripped
over tiny crevices on the side
walks. | have plunged into gopher

More than 200, 900 youngsters bdYaded
through the streets shouting and demon
-stfating. TheysaOeYe not as dedicated nor
as foyceful as The first group whO Demon
"styated several weeks ago. This movement
dM not haze the sanction or support Of the
three largest c1vil rights groups, namely
the National A sociation for the Advance
ment of Coloyed People, the National Urban
League or the Congress for Ra cial Equality.
In place of some calmey and saner leaders
--Jhis GROUP mas not led rather, 1t oOas
melted by the dramatic Harlem Congressman
Reu. Adam c. POWELL He shared the center
Of attention and unfortunately urged the young
PEOPLE to keep up the pressure.


+:A1y. Powell foygets that he has led a
usaiaue life in America. AS the son OF a we'll
to do Harlem minister and founder OF the
lrygest Negro church I'M the countrywide
baas literally born poles apart from the UeTy
beoble he processes to represent. He qu1ckE
raises his voice to aid 1.-THE blacks "-and
encourages them to- revolt. But where does
Ep%gO vhen he wants to re lax and seek ref
uge =? He goes to his Uilla by the sea IN
Puerto Rico He keeps an apartment IN
Harlem where he rarely visits. He MINIS
tsys to the largest Negro congregations
bit he feels he mast align with Malcolm
Xsand preach revolution.


5s.Little can be gained If our young Ne
EYoes are led to believe that fights and
undeys ta,uding .Oiu be earned in the streets
of NeoV York or any other tO1Vm.
